title: China asks its carmakers to keep key EV technology at home
content: China has urged its carmakers to keep advanced EV technology within the country, even as they build factories abroad to avoid tariffs. The Ministry of Commerce advised exporting knock-down kits for final assembly overseas and warned against investments in India. This move aims to protect China's EV industry know-how.

title: Global automotive ER&D spending expected to soar, with focus on digital vehicles, sustainability and AI integration: BCG Report
content: Investment in automotive engineering research and development is expected to grow annually by 8–9% until 2030, reaching up to USD 540 billion. Key drivers include advancements in connected mobility, digital vehicles, sustainability, and artificial intelligence. Automakers face challenges balancing software costs while integrating eco-friendly technology and AI-based systems.

title: Honda partners with IIT Delhi and IIT Bombay for advanced AI research in automated driving technologies

title: California passes requirements on carmakers and domestic violence
content: California lawmakers have approved a proposal requiring automakers to enhance protections for domestic abuse survivors using internet-connected cars. The bill mandates carmakers to establish processes for restraining order submissions and to allow drivers to disable location access. Governor Gavin Newsom will decide on the bill by Sept. 30.

title: Musk denies report his xAI in talks over Tesla revenue

title: Tesla shares gain on plans to launch full self-driving in Europe, China
content: Tesla shares increased by 2.5% after the company confirmed plans to launch its Full Self-Driving software in China and Europe, pending regulatory approval. title: How India can leverage biofuels to build a sustainable future
content: Derived from renewable resources such as biomass and agricultural waste, biofuels provide a cleaner alternative to conventional fossil fuels in our energy palettes, for meeting needs, whether it is surface mobility, aviation, shipping, or even power production. Today, it is possible to leverage bioenergy to fuel each of these energy needs and that also with lower permanent emissions. India has achieved an avoidance of as much as 1.5 tonnes of GHG emissions per kilolitre of bio-ethanol replacing petrol in our cars, amounting to more than 40 million tonnes of savings in GHG emissions over the last decade.
